[[17]](#cite_note-Gilead_PR_20201022-17) Remdesivir was originally developed to treat [hepatitis C](/wiki/Hepatitis_C), [[18]](#cite_note-Stephens2-18) and was subsequently investigated for [Ebola virus disease](/wiki/Ebola) and [Marburg virus](/wiki/Marburg_virus_disease) infections [[19]](#cite_note-pmid269342202-19) before as post-infection treatment for COVID19. [[20]](#cite_note-kai2-20) Remdesivir is a [prodrug](/wiki/Prodrug) that is intended to allow intracellular delivery of [GS-441524](/wiki/GS-441524) [[21]](#cite_note-Yan_2020-21) The most common side effect in healthy volunteers is raised blood levels of [liver enzymes](/wiki/Liver_enzymes). [[12]](#cite_note-Veklury_EPAR-12) The most common side effect in people with COVID19 is [nausea](/wiki/Nausea). [[12]](#cite_note-Veklury_EPAR-12) Side effects may include liver inflammation and an [infusion](/wiki/Intravenous_therapy)-related reaction with nausea, [low blood pressure](/wiki/Hypotension), and sweating. [[22]](#cite_note-FDA_Remdesivir_EUA_Fact_Sheet-22) The U.S. [Food and Drug Administration](/wiki/Food_and_Drug_Administration) (FDA) considers it to be a [first-in-class medication](/wiki/First-in-class_medication). [[23]](#cite_note-23) Medical uses In the European Union, remdesivir is [indicated](/wiki/Indication_(medicine)) for the treatment of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID19) in adults and adolescents (aged twelve years and older with body weight at least 40 kilograms (88 lb)) with [pneumonia](/wiki/Pneumonia) requiring supplemental oxygen and for adults who do not require supplemental oxygen and who are at increased risk of progressing to severe COVID19. [[9]](#cite_note-Veklury_SmPC-9) [[12]](#cite_note-Veklury_EPAR-12) In the United States, remdesivir is indicated for the treatment of COVID19 in people 28 days of age and older and weighing at least 3 kilograms (6.6 lb) who are hospitalized; or not hospitalized and have mild-to-moderate COVID19, and are at high risk for progression to severe COVID19, including hospitalization or death. [[11]](#cite_note-Veklury_FDA_label-11) [[24]](#cite_note-FDA_PR_20220425-24) In November 2020, the FDA issued an emergency use authorization (EUA) for the combination of [baricitinib](/wiki/Baricitinib) with remdesivir, for the treatment of suspected or laboratory confirmed COVID19 in hospitalized people two years of age or older requiring supplemental oxygen, invasive mechanical ventilation, or [extracorporeal membrane oxygenation](/wiki/Extracorporeal_membrane_oxygenation) (ECMO). [[25]](#cite_note-FDA_PR_202011192-25) In Australia, it is approved for those aged four weeks of age and older with a body weight at least 3 kilograms (6.6 lb) with [pneumonia](/wiki/Pneumonia) requiring supplemental oxygen or those aged four weeks of age and older with body weight at least 40 kilograms (88 lb) who do not require supplemental oxygen and who are at high risk of progressing to severe COVID19. [[26]](#cite_note-26) [[2]](#cite_note-AusPAR:_Remdesivir-2) Side effects The most common adverse effects in people treated with remdesivir were [respiratory failure](/wiki/Respiratory_failure) and and [elevated adverse effects levels in the may cause [infusion-related](/wiki/Intravenous_therapy) reactions, including low blood pressure, nausea, vomiting, sweating or shivering. [[28]](#cite_note-EUA_FAQ2-28) Other possible side effects of remdesivir include: - Infusion-related reactions. Infusion-related reactions have been seen during a remdesivir infusion or around the time remdesivir was given. [[28]](#cite_note-EUA_FAQ2-28)Signs and symptoms of infusion-related reactions may include: low blood pressure, nausea, vomiting, sweating, and shivering. [[28]](#cite_note-EUA_FAQ2-28) - Increases in levels of liver enzymes, seen in abnormal liver blood tests. [[28]](#cite_note-EUA_FAQ2-28)Increases in levels of liver enzymes have been seen in people who have received remdesivir, which may be a sign of inflammation or damage to cells in the liver. [[28]](#cite_note-EUA_FAQ2-28) Pharmacology Activation Remdesivir is a [protide](/wiki/Protide) ( [prodrug](/wiki/Prodrug) of nucleotide) able to diffuse into cells, where it is converted to [GS-441524](/wiki/GS-441524) monophosphate via the actions of and a [phosphoamidase](/wiki/Phosphoamidase) ( bioactivation is meant to occur [intracellularly](/wiki/Intracellular), but a substantial amount of remdesivir is prematurely [hydrolyzed](/wiki/Hydrolysis) in plasma, with GS-441524 being the major metabolite in plasma, and the only metabolite remaining two hours after dosing. [[21]](#cite_note-Yan_2020-21) Mechanism of action [[32]](#cite_note-pmid22446091-32) the [active of viral RNA polymerase](/wiki/RNA-dependent_RNA_polymerase) and evades [proofreading](/wiki/Proofreading_(biology)) by viral [exoribonuclease](/wiki/Exoribonuclease) (ExoN), causing a decrease in viral RNA production. [[14]](#cite_note-Scavone_2020-14) [[33]](#cite_note-Ferner2020-33) In some viruses, such as the [respiratory syncytial virus](/wiki/Respiratory_syncytial_virus), it causes the RNA-dependent RNA polymerases to pause, but its predominant effect (as in Ebola) is to induce an irreversible [chain termination](/wiki/Chain_termination). Unlike with many other chain terminators, this is not mediated by preventing addition of the immediately subsequent nucleotide, but is instead delayed, occurring after five additional bases have been added to the growing RNA chain. [[34]](#cite_note-pmid30987343-34) For the RNA-Dependent RNA Polymerase of MERS-CoV, SARS-CoV-1, and SARS-CoV-2, arrest of RNA synthesis occurs after incorporation of three additional nucleotides. [[35]](#cite_note-Gordon_2020-35) [[31]](#cite_note-Gordon2020-31) Hence, remdesivir is classified as a direct-acting antiviral agent that works as a delayed chain terminator. [[29]](#cite_note-Eastman_2020-29) [[31]](#cite_note-Gordon2020-31) Pharmacokinetics In non-human primates, the plasma [half-life](/wiki/Biological_half-life) of the prodrug is 20 minutes, with the main metabolite being the [nucleoside](/wiki/Nucleoside), [GS-441524](/wiki/GS-441524). Two hours post injection, the main metabolite GS-441524 is present at micromolar concentrations, whilst intact Remdesivir is no longer detectable. Because of this rapid extracellular conversion to the nucleoside GS-441524, some researchers have questioned whether the active nucleotide triphosphate is truly derived from Remdesivir pro-drug removal or whether it occurs by GS-441524 phosphorylation, and whether direct administration of GS-441524 would constitute a cheaper and easier to administer COVID19 drug compared to Remdesivir. [[36]](#cite_note-Yan_2020_2-36) [[21]](#cite_note-Yan_2020-21) The activated nucleotide triphosphate form has sustained intracellular levels in [PBMC](/wiki/PBMC) and presumably in other cells as well. [[29]](#cite_note-Eastman_2020-29) Resistance Mutations in the [mouse hepatitis virus](/wiki/Mouse_hepatitis_virus) [RNA replicase](/wiki/RNA_replicase) that cause partial resistance to remdesivir were identified in 2018. These mutations make the viruses less effective in nature, and the researchers believe they will likely not persist where the drug is not being used. [[37]](#cite_note-Chiotos2020-37) Interactions Remdesivir is at least partially metabolized by of remdesivir are expected to decrease if it is administered together with cytochrome P450 Coadministration of remdesivir and chloroquine phosphate or hydroxychloroquine sulfate is not recommended based on in vitro data demonstrating an antagonistic effect of chloroquine on the intracellular metabolic activation and antiviral activity of remdesivir. [[11]](#cite_note-Veklury_FDA_label-11) Synthesis Remdesivir can be synthesized in multiple steps from [ribose](/wiki/Ribose) derivatives. The figure to the right is one of the synthesis routes of remdesivir invented by Chun and coauthors from Gilead Sciences. [[41]](#cite_note-41) [[42]](#cite_note-42) In this method, intermediate a is firstly prepared from L- [alanine](/wiki/Alanine) and phenyl phosphorodichloridate in presence of [triethylamine](/wiki/Triethylamine) oxidized [1,2,4]triazin-4-amine is brominated, and excess [trimethylsilyl chloride](/wiki/Trimethylsilyl_chloride). [n-Butyllithium](/wiki/N-Butyllithium) undergoes a [halogen-lithium exchange](/wiki/Organolithium_reagent) reaction with the bromide at 78 °C (108 °F) to yield the intermediate c. The intermediate b is then added to a solution containing intermediate c dropwise. After quenching the reaction in a weakly acidic aqueous solution, a mixture of 1:1 [anomers](/wiki/Anomer) was obtained. It was then reacted with an excess of [trimethylsilyl cyanide](/wiki/Trimethylsilyl_cyanide) in dichloromethane at 78 °C (108 °F) for 10 minutes. [Trimethylsilyl triflate](/wiki/Trimethylsilyl_triflate) was added and reacts for one additional hour, and the mixture was quenched in an aqueous sodium hydrogen carbonate. A [nitrile](/wiki/Nitrile) intermediate was obtained. The protective group, benzyl, was then removed with [boron trichloride](/wiki/Boron_trichloride) in dichloromethane at 20 °C (4 °F). The excess of boron trichloride was quenched in a mixture of potassium carbonate and methanol. A benzyl-free intermediate was obtained. The isomers were then separated via reversed-phase [HPLC](/wiki/High-performance_liquid_chromatography). The optically pure compound and intermediate a are reacted with trimethyl phosphate and methylimidazole to obtain a [diastereomer](/wiki/Diastereomer) mixture of remdesivir. In the end, optically pure remdesivir can be obtained through [chiral resolution](/wiki/Chiral_resolution) methods.[ [citation vitro experiments An study of remdesivir assessing antiviral activity against SARS-CoV-2 was performed. [[44]](#cite_note-Langreth-44) In January 2020, Gilead began working on restarting remdesivir production in glass-lined steel [chemical reactors](/wiki/Chemical_reactor) at its manufacturing plant in [Edmonton, Alberta](/wiki/Edmonton). [[44]](#cite_note-Langreth-44) On 2 February 2020, the company flew its entire stock of remdesivir, 100 kilograms in powder form (left over from Ebola research), to its filling plant in [La Verne, California](/wiki/La_Verne,_California) to start filling vials. [[44]](#cite_note-Langreth-44) The Edmonton plant finished its first new batch of remdesivir in April 2020. [[45]](#cite_note-Pipkin-45) On 12 May 2020, Gilead announced that it had granted non-exclusive voluntary licenses to five [generic drug](/wiki/Generic_drug) companies in India and Pakistan to manufacture remdesivir for distribution to 127 countries. [[46]](#cite_note-Silverman-46) [[47]](#cite_note-47) [[48]](#cite_note-Gilead_licensing-48) The agreements were structured so that the licensees can set their own prices and will not have to pay royalties to Gilead until the WHO declares an end to the COVID19 emergency or another medicine or vaccine is approved for COVID19, whichever comes first. [[46]](#cite_note-Silverman-46) On 23 June 2020, India granted emergency marketing approval of generic remdesivir manufactured by two Gilead licensees, [Cipla](/wiki/Cipla) and [Hetero Drugs](/wiki/Hetero_Drugs). [[49]](#cite_note-Rajagopal-49) Society and culture Legal status Remdesivir is approved, or authorized for emergency use, to treat COVID19 in many countries. [[70]](#cite_note-EU_compassionate-70) Individuals who receive a five-day treatment course but do not show clinical improvement will be eligible to continue receiving remdesivir for an additional five days. [[106]](#cite_note-FDA_PR_20221021-106) Economics In June 2020, Gilead announced that it had set the price of remdesivir at US$390 per vial for the governments of developed countries, including the United States, and US$520 for US private health insurance companies. [[107]](#cite_note-Gilead_PR_20200629-107) The expected course of treatment is six vials over five days for a total cost of US$2,340. [[107]](#cite_note-Gilead_PR_20200629-107) Being a [repurposed drug](/wiki/Drug_repositioning), the minimum production cost for remdesivir is estimated at US$0.93 per day of treatment. [[108]](#cite_note-108) In July 2020, the European Union secured a €63 million (US$74 million) contract with Gilead, to make the drug available there in early August 2020. [[109]](#cite_note-109) In October 2020, Gilead Sciences and the European Commission announced they had signed a joint procurement framework contract in which Gilead agreed to provide up to 500,000 remdesivir treatment courses over the next six months to 37 European countries. Among the contracting countries were all 27 EU member states plus the United Kingdom, "Albania, Bosnia & Herzegovina, Iceland, Kosovo, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Norway, and Serbia". [[110]](#cite_note-Saigol-110) At the time, the price per treatment course was not disclosed; Reuters reported the price was 2,070 euros, thereby implying the total value of the contract (if all 500,000 courses are ordered) is approximately €1.035 billion. [[111]](#cite_note-Guarascio-111) Under the contract, each participating country will directly place orders with Gilead and pay Gilead directly for its own orders. [[111]](#cite_note-Guarascio-111) Names Remdesivir is the [international nonproprietary name](/wiki/International_nonproprietary_name) (INN) [[112]](#cite_note-112) the development code name was GS-5734. [[113]](#cite_note-113) Research Remdesivir was originally created and developed by [Gilead Sciences](/wiki/Gilead_Sciences) in (RSV). [[18]](#cite_note-Stephens2-18) C or RSV, [[18]](#cite_note-Stephens2-18) [[114]](#cite_note-NIH_20201023-114) but was then repurposed and studied as a potential treatment for [Ebola virus disease](/wiki/Ebola_virus_disease) and [Marburg virus](/wiki/Marburg_virus) infections. [[115]](#cite_note-Warren_2016-115) [[114]](#cite_note-NIH_20201023-114) According to the [Czech News Agency](/wiki/Czech_News_Agency), this new line of research was carried out under the direction of scientist [Tomá Cihlá](/wiki/Tom%C3%A1%C5%A1_Cihl%C3%A1%C5%99). [[116]](#cite_note-116) A collaboration of researchers from the [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention](/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention) (CDC) and [Gilead Sciences](/wiki/Gilead_Sciences) subsequently discovered that remdesivir had antiviral activity in vitro against multiple [filoviruses](/wiki/Filovirus), [pneumoviruses](/wiki/Pneumovirus), paramyxoviruses, and [coronaviruses](/wiki/Coronavirus). [[117]](#cite_note-Lo_2017-117) Preclinical and clinical research and development was done in collaboration between Gilead Sciences and various US government agencies and academic institutions. [[29]](#cite_note-Eastman_2020-29) [[118]](#cite_note-118) [[119]](#cite_note-119) [[120]](#cite_note-120) During the mid-2010s, the [Mintz Levin](/wiki/Mintz,_Levin,_Cohn,_Ferris,_Glovsky,_and_Popeo) law firm prosecuted various patent applications for remdesivir on behalf of Gilead Sciences before the [United States Patent and Trademark Office](/wiki/United_States_Patent_and_Trademark_Office) (USPTO). The USPTO granted two patents on remdesivir to Gilead Sciences on 9 April 2019: one for filoviruses, [[121]](#cite_note-121) and one which covered both [arenaviruses](/wiki/Arenavirus) and coronaviruses. [[122]](#cite_note-122) Ebola In October 2015, the [United States Army Medical Research Institute of Infectious Diseases](/wiki/United_States_Army_Medical_Research_Institute_of_Infectious_Diseases) (USAMRIID) announced preclinical results that remdesivir had blocked the [Ebola virus](/wiki/Ebola_virus) in [Rhesus monkeys](/wiki/Rhesus_monkeys). Travis Warren, who has been a USAMRIID principal investigator since 2007, said that the "work is a result of the continuing collaboration between USAMRIID and Gilead Sciences". [[123]](#cite_note-USAMRIID_20151009-123) The "initial screening" of the "Gilead Sciences compound library to find molecules with promising antiviral activity" was performed by scientists at the [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention](/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention) (CDC). [[123]](#cite_note-USAMRIID_20151009-123) As a result of this work, it was recommended that remdesivir "should be further developed as a potential treatment." [[115]](#cite_note-Warren_2016-115)[ [unreliable medical source?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Identifying_reliable_sources_(medicine))] [[123]](#cite_note-USAMRIID_20151009-123) Remdesivir was rapidly pushed through clinical trials due to the [West African Ebola virus epidemic](/wiki/West_African_Ebola_virus_epidemic) of 2013-2016, eventually being used in people with the disease. Preliminary results were promising; it was used in the emergency setting during the [Kivu Ebola epidemic](/wiki/Kivu_Ebola_epidemic) that started in 2018, along with further clinical trials, until August 2019, when Congolese health officials announced that it was significantly less effective than [monoclonal antibody](/wiki/Monoclonal_antibody) treatments such as [ansuvimab](/wiki/Ansuvimab) and [atoltivimab/maftivimab/odesivimab](/wiki/Atoltivimab/maftivimab/odesivimab). The trials, however, established its safety profile. [[124]](#cite_note-124) COVID-19 Hospitalized patients Remdesivir was approved for medical use in the United States in October 2020. [[57]](#cite_note-FDA_Veklury-57) [[58]](#cite_note-Veklury:_Summary_Review-58) [[59]](#cite_note-FDA_PR_20201022-59) [[104]](#cite_note-FDA_snapshot-104) The U.S. [Food and Drug Administration](/wiki/Food_and_Drug_Administration) (FDA) approved remdesivir based on the agency's analysis of data from three randomized, controlled clinical trials that included participants hospitalized with mild-to-severe COVID19. [[59]](#cite_note-FDA_PR_20201022-59) [[104]](#cite_note-FDA_snapshot-104) The FDA granted approval and reissued the revised EUA to Gilead Sciences Inc. [[59]](#cite_note-FDA_PR_20201022-59) The FDA approved remdesivir based primarily on evidence from three clinical trials (NCT04280705, NCT04292899, and NCT04292730) of 2043 hospitalized participants with COVID19. [[104]](#cite_note-FDA_snapshot-104) The trials were conducted at 226 sites in 17 countries including the United States. [[104]](#cite_note-FDA_snapshot-104) In November 2020, the World Health Organization (WHO) updated its guideline on therapeutics for COVID19 to include a conditional recommendation against the use of remdesivir, triggered by results from the WHO [Solidarity trial](/wiki/Solidarity_trial). [[125]](#cite_note-WHO_guidelines-125) COVID19 Clinical Pharmacology Task Group recommended that remdesivir only be administered to hospitalized patients as part of a [randomized controlled trial](/wiki/Randomized_controlled_trial) due to limited information on risks and benefits. [[129]](#cite_note-129) In January 2022, the Canadian component of the WHO Solidarity Trial reported that in-hospital people with COVID19 treated with remdesivir had 17% lower relative risk of death (18.7% versus 22.6% death rates) and 47% reduced relative risk for needing oxygen and mechanical ventilation (8.0% versus 15.0%) compared to people receiving standard-of-care treatments. [[130]](#cite_note-Ali-130) In September 2022, the WHO updated their guidelines to recommend use of remdesivir for both non-hospitalized and hospitalized patients. [[131]](#cite_note-131) This was based on final results from the SOLIDARITY trial that showed a reduction in mortality or progression to mechanical ventilation for non-ventilated patients. Nonhospitalized outpatients In January 2022, a study indicated that nonhospitalized people who were at high risk for COVID19 progression had an 87% lower risk of hospitalization or death after a 3-day course of intravenous remdesivir. [[132]](#cite_note-132) Remdesivir/baricitinib In May 2020, the [National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases](/wiki/National_Institute_of_Allergy_and_Infectious_Diseases) (NIAID) started the Adaptive COVID19 Treatment Trial 2 (ACTT-2) to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a treatment regimen consisting of remdesivir plus [baricitinib](/wiki/Baricitinib) for treating hospitalized adults who have a laboratory-confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection with evidence of lung involvement, including a need for supplemental oxygen, abnormal chest X-rays, or illness requiring mechanical ventilation. [[133]](#cite_note-133) [[134]](#cite_note-ACTT_3_PR-134) [[135]](#cite_note-135) In November 2020, the U.S. [Food and Drug Administration](/wiki/Food_and_Drug_Administration) (FDA) issued an [emergency use authorization](/wiki/Emergency_use_authorization) (EUA) for the drug baricitinib, in combination with remdesivir, for the treatment of suspected or laboratory-confirmed COVID19 in hospitalized people two years of age or older requiring supplemental oxygen, invasive mechanical ventilation, or [extracorporeal membrane oxygenation](/wiki/Extracorporeal_membrane_oxygenation) (ECMO). [[25]](#cite_note-FDA_PR_202011192-25) The data supporting the EUA for baricitinib with remdesivir are based on a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial (ACTT-2), which was conducted by the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID). [[25]](#cite_note-FDA_PR_202011192-25) The EUA was issued to Eli Lilly and Company. [[25]](#cite_note-FDA_PR_202011192-25) Remdesivir/interferon beta-1a In August 2020, the NIAID started the Adaptive COVID19 Treatment Trial 3 (ACTT 3) to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a treatment regimen consisting of remdesivir plus [interferon beta-1a](/wiki/Interferon_beta-1a) for hospitalized adults who have a laboratory-confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection with evidence of lung involvement, including a need for supplemental oxygen, abnormal chest X-rays, or illness requiring mechanical ventilation. [[134]](#cite_note-ACTT_3_PR-134) [[136]](#cite_note-136) Veterinary uses In 2019, GS-441524 was shown to have promise for treating [feline infectious peritonitis](/wiki/Feline_infectious_peritonitis) caused by a [coronavirus](/wiki/Feline_coronavirus). [[137]](#cite_note-pedersen-137) It has not been evaluated or approved by the US [Food and Drug Administration](/wiki/Food_and_Drug_Administration) (FDA) for the treatment of [feline coronavirus](/wiki/Feline_coronavirus) or feline infectious peritonitis but has been available since 2019, through websites and social media as an unregulated black market substance. [[138]](#cite_note-138) Because GS-441524 is the main circulating metabolite of remdesivir and because GS-441524 has similar potency against SARS-Cov-2 in vitro, some researchers have argued for the direct administration of GS-441524 as a COVID19 treatment.
